• The establishment of a free economic zone in Tangier significantly boosted the city’s economic output, positioning it as an industrial hub within Morocco.
• The most substantial investment was the creation of the Tanger-Med port, which is recognized as the largest port in both Africa and the Mediterranean region.
• Tangier is currently experiencing an economic boom, which necessitated the development of a commercial district known as Tangier City Center, officially inaugurated in 2016.
• In 2012, the Renault Tanger Méditerranée automobile manufacturing plant commenced operations, achieving an annual production capacity exceeding 250,000 vehicles.
• The Mohammed VI Bridge is recognized as the longest suspended bridge in Africa, symbolizing Morocco's modern infrastructure development efforts.
• Newly constructed roads are part of a development program specifically targeting the southern provinces of Morocco, aiming to enhance connectivity and economic integration.
• The Al Boraq RGV2N2 high-speed trainset was operational at Tanger Ville railway station as of November 2018, marking a significant advancement in Morocco’s rail transport capabilities.

• Tanger-Med port, located in the Tangiers free economic zone, is the largest port in Africa and the Mediterranean, ranked 18th globally with a container handling capacity exceeding 9 million containers, serving as a major logistics hub for Africa and international trade.

• According to the Global Competitiveness Report of 2019, Morocco achieved the following infrastructure rankings globally: 16th in Roads, 16th in Sea transport, 45th in Air transport, and 64th in Railways, making it the highest-ranked African country in these categories.
• The Moroccan government prioritizes modern infrastructure development, including ports, airports, and rail links, to support economic growth and meet increasing domestic demand.
• Between 2010 and 2015, Morocco invested over $15 billion in upgrading its basic infrastructure, reflecting a substantial commitment to enhancing national transport and logistics networks.

• Morocco possesses one of the continent’s best road systems, having constructed approximately 1,770 kilometers of modern roads over the past 20 years, primarily toll expressways connecting major cities.

• The Moroccan Ministry of Equipment, Transport, Logistics, and Water plans to build an additional 3,380 kilometers of expressways and 2,100 kilometers of highways by 2030, with an estimated investment cost of $9.6 billion.
• A key focus of road infrastructure expansion is linking the southern provinces, particularly the cities of Laayoune and Dakhla, to the rest of Morocco to promote regional development.

• In 2014, Morocco commenced construction of Africa’s second high-speed railway system, connecting Tangiers and Casablanca, which was inaugurated in 2018 by King Mohammed VI after over a decade of planning and construction by the Moroccan national railway company ONCF.

• The Tangiers-Casablanca high-speed rail line represents the first phase of a planned 1,500-kilometer (930-mile) high-speed rail network across Morocco, with extensions to Marrakesh already in planning stages.

• Between 1998 and 2007, the Moroccan economy experienced significant growth, with the national income increasing at an average annual rate of 5.5%, leading to notable progress in national income, employment, and living standards.

• Despite this economic growth, substantial disparities persisted in the distribution of its benefits, manifesting between different production factors, socio-economic groups, and between urban and rural areas.
• The improvement in national income during the 1998–2007 decade was insufficient to adequately address the disparities in living standards and the magnitude of social deficits within Morocco.

• Over the last ten years preceding the report, the real income of the Moroccan population increased annually by 2.5%, a figure that accounts for fluctuations caused by climatic conditions which disproportionately impact the most vulnerable populations and their living standards.

• A national survey on Moroccans' living standards in 2001 revealed that the wealthiest 10% of the population accounted for consumption expenses twelve times greater than those of the poorest 10%, highlighting significant inequality in consumption.

• Although disparities in consumption and living standards tend to decrease within urban areas, the data underscore the critical need for intensified efforts to reduce economic inequality across the country.
• Approximately one-third of Morocco's population is employed in the agricultural sector, reflecting the country's reliance on farming activities for employment.

• Another one-third of the population earns their livelihood through mining, manufacturing, and construction industries, indicating a significant portion of the workforce engaged in industrial and infrastructural development.
• The remaining segment of the workforce is occupied in trade, finance, and service sectors, highlighting the diversity of employment opportunities beyond primary and secondary industries.

• These employment estimates do not account for a substantial informal economy comprising street vendors, domestic workers, and other underemployed or poorly paid individuals, suggesting that actual labor dynamics are broader and more complex.

• Morocco faces a significant challenge with high unemployment rates; the official unemployment figure stands at roughly 10% of the workforce, though unofficial estimates suggest the real rate is considerably higher.

• Unemployment is particularly acute among university graduates holding nontechnical degrees, a trend consistent with patterns observed across most Middle Eastern and North African countries, indicating a mismatch between education and labor market demands.

• The country hosts several trade unions, with the largest being L'Union Marocaine du Travail, which boasts nearly 700,000 members and is affiliated with the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, reflecting organized labor's presence and international connections in Morocco.
• Morocco's unemployment rate, historically a significant concern, experienced a steady decline in 2008, driven primarily by job growth in the services and construction sectors.
• Institutional reforms aimed at enhancing competitiveness and financial openness are anticipated to sustain the downward trend in unemployment.
• Despite economic growth, the unemployment rate is not expected to decrease substantially due to the continuous increase in the number of first-time labor market entrants.
• Between 1999 and 2005, urban unemployment in Morocco decreased from 22% to 18.3%, while the national unemployment rate fell from 13.9% to 10.8%.
• According to the State High Planning Commission, Morocco’s official unemployment rate declined to 9.1% in the second quarter of 2008, down from 9.6% in the first quarter of the same year.
• The total number of unemployed individuals in Morocco was approximately 1.03 million in Q2 2008, compared to 1.06 million at the end of March 2008.
• At the end of 2007, the unemployment rate stood at 9.8%, representing a slight increase of 0.1% from the end of 2006.
• Urban areas experienced particularly strong job growth, with the services and construction sectors being the primary contributors to employment creation.
• The services sector generated approximately 152,000 new jobs, notably driven by the business process outsourcing (BPO) and telecommunications industries.
• The construction sector created around 80,000 new jobs in the second quarter of 2008, supported by government infrastructure projects and substantial private investment in real estate and tourism.
• The declining unemployment trend in Morocco is positive, especially considering that joblessness has been a serious issue across North Africa.

• Morocco’s unemployment rate is lower than that of its Maghreb neighbors, with Tunisia at approximately 13.9% and Algeria at about 12.3%, yet unemployment remains a significant economic and social challenge.
• A 2006 government report indicated that Morocco requires a net increase of 400,000 jobs annually for the next twenty years to accommodate its demographic growth and provide sufficient employment.
• The Moroccan labor market may face additional pressure from returning workers due to economic difficulties faced by Spanish construction firms, potentially increasing unemployment challenges.
• According to the CIA, 30.5% of Morocco’s population of 34.3 million is aged 14 or younger, making youth employment a critical government priority.
• Data from 2007 show that 17.6% of individuals aged 15–24 in Morocco were unemployed.

• Youth unemployment rises to about one-third in urban areas, whereas rural youth often find employment in agriculture, including family farms, immediately after leaving school, contributing to higher youth employment rates in rural regions.
• Lower levels of official unemployment registration in rural areas also contribute to the disparity in youth unemployment statistics between urban and rural communities.
• A 2010 report estimated that approximately 150,000 children aged between 5 and 14 were engaged in child labour in Morocco.
• The predominant sectors employing child labour in Morocco are agriculture and domestic services.
• Young girls working as live-in domestic servants are locally referred to as _petites bonnes_ (little maids), many of whom are aged 10 years or younger.

• These _petites bonnes_ typically originate from very poor families and experience conditions akin to involuntary servitude, including long working hours without breaks, absence of holidays, physical, verbal, and sexual abuse, withheld wages, and restrictions on their freedom of movement.
• _Petites bonnes_ are systematically denied access to education.
• More visible forms of child labour in Morocco include street children in major cities such as Casablanca, Marrakech, Fès, and Mèknes.
• Street children survive by engaging in activities such as selling cigarettes, begging, shining shoes, washing cars, and working as porters and packers in ports.
• The Ministry of Planning in Morocco estimates that the number of _petites bonnes_ in the country ranges between 60,000 and 100,000.
• Government-commissioned studies identify poverty and lack of access to schooling, often in combination, as the primary causes of the _petites bonnes_ phenomenon in Morocco.

• Additionally, rural parents commonly hold the belief that education or obtaining a diploma will not improve their daughters’ employment prospects, contributing to the perpetuation of child domestic labour.

• Morocco possesses very limited domestic energy reserves and was significantly impacted by the high oil prices experienced in 2007 and early 2008, necessitating the importation of 96% of its energy requirements.
• The national oil import bill for Morocco in the first quarter of 2008 reached $1.1 billion, representing a 69% increase compared to the same period in 2007.
• According to the International Energy Agency (IEA) report of 2014, Morocco remains highly dependent on imported energy, with over 91% of its energy supply sourced from abroad.

• Morocco is actively pursuing diversification of its energy sources, with a strategic emphasis on developing renewable energy, particularly wind energy; solar power and nuclear energy are also included in this strategy.
• Development of solar power in Morocco has been slow, and progress on nuclear energy has been minimal, aside from a 2007 announcement of collaboration with France on nuclear energy initiatives.
• In November 2009, Morocco announced a $9 billion solar energy project intended to account for 38% of the country's installed power generation capacity by 2020.
• The 2009 solar project involves the establishment of five solar power generation sites across Morocco, aiming to produce 2,000 megawatts (MW) of electricity by 2020.
• Funding for the solar energy project is planned to come from a combination of private and state capital.
• The announcement ceremony for the solar project was attended by U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and the Moroccan king, underscoring international support.
• Germany has expressed willingness to participate in Morocco’s solar energy project and in the development of a water-desalination plant, with the World Bank also supporting the solar initiative.

• The Moroccan government intends to reorganize its energy subsidy system, which currently imposes a heavy burden on government finances; although subsidies help ease consumer costs in the short term, they are unsustainable if they continue to rise indefinitely.

• National energy consumption per capita in Morocco is projected to increase from 0.4 tonnes of oil equivalent (toe) currently to as much as 0.90 toe by 2030, reflecting both development progress and significant future energy challenges.
• The integration of renewable energy sources is considered critically important to Morocco’s future energy strategy.

• According to a 2006 estimate by the Oil and Gas Journal (OGJ), Morocco’s proven oil reserves stand at 1,070,000 barrels (170,000 cubic meters), and proven natural gas reserves are estimated at 60 billion cubic feet (1.7×10^9 cubic meters).

• Morocco may possess additional hydrocarbon reserves, as many of its sedimentary basins remain unexplored; the Moroccan Office of Hydrocarbons and Mining (ONHYM) has expressed optimism about discovering further reserves, especially offshore, following recent discoveries in neighboring Mauritania.
• Exploration activities in Western Sahara, a territory believed to contain viable hydrocarbon reserves, have been controversial due to competing claims and licenses.

• In 2001, Morocco granted exploration contracts in Western Sahara to TotalEnergies and Kerr-McGee, which caused conflict with Premier Oil and Sterling Energy, companies that had previously obtained licenses from the Polisario government.
• In 2005, the government-in-exile of Western Sahara invited foreign companies to bid on 12 offshore exploration contracts, aiming to award production sharing contracts by the end of that year.

• Total energy consumption in Morocco has increased significantly over the decades, measured in Terrawatt-hours (TWh) as follows: 30 TWh in 1970; 61 TWh in 1980; 83 TWh in 1990; 117 TWh in 2000; 195 TWh in 2010; 243 TWh in 2020; and 271 TWh in 2023.

• Per capita energy consumption in Morocco, measured in Kilowatt-hours (KWh), has also risen steadily: 1,989 KWh in 1970; 3,088 KWh in 1980; 3,368 KWh in 1990; 4,114 KWh in 2000; 6,005 KWh in 2010; 6,611 KWh in 2020; and 7,169 KWh in 2023.

• Morocco’s shift towards an environment-conscious approach has generated numerous investment opportunities, primarily in the utility and renewable energy sectors, including increased sales of photovoltaic panels and a surge in the wind turbine market despite rising international prices due to growing demand.

• To advance sustainable development, Morocco requires technological upgrades such as improvements in automobile technology, enhancement of energy product quality, and expansion of renewable energy-producing plants, alongside government initiatives to promote water conservation and efficiency to combat scarcity.
• Morocco’s environmental efforts were internationally recognized when the Mohammed VI Foundation for Environment received the National Energy Globe Award in Brussels in 2007.

• Morocco is considered a model for water management within the MENA region, with ongoing upgrades under the National Wastewater Management Programme aimed at improving wastewater treatment and maximizing efficient water use.

• Agricultural water use, which accounts for 80% of Morocco’s water resources, is being rationalized through the replacement of traditional irrigation systems with micro-irrigation and drip irrigation networks to enhance water efficiency.

• As a net energy importer, Morocco launched the National Renewable Energy and Efficiency Plan in February 2008, targeting the development of alternative energy sources to satisfy 15% of domestic energy needs and promote energy-saving methods, with expectations to create over 40,000 jobs and attract more than €4.5 billion in investments by 2020.
• The National Plan for the Development of Solar Thermal Energy, established in 2001, aimed to install 440,000 solar-powered water heaters by 2012, with 235,000 units completed by that time.
• In May 2009, the World Bank approved a €121 million loan to support Morocco’s solid-waste management programme, which aims to achieve a 90% waste disposal rate in urban areas by 2021.
• The Moroccan government is implementing measures to mitigate the environmental impact of tourism on natural resources while promoting ecotourism projects through increased incentives.

• Since January 2008, hotels demonstrating good environmental practices are eligible to receive the Green Key label, a certification program administered by the Mohammed VI Foundation for the Protection of the Environment.
• Under a ten-year natural resource protection plan, Morocco annually replants between 40,000 and 50,000 hectares of forests with indigenous palm trees to restore and conserve forested areas.
